Replace.Text: New Jersey

Iowa class battleship, flagship of the Third and Fifth Fleets, Garden State. New Jersey, you are the most honorable battleship in history, with a reputation both inside and out. As a flagship, your bravery on the battlefield is truly amazing. Now, fight for freedom and justice, and live up to the honor you have.
It was the most honorable battleship in the history of the United States Navy
As the most honorable battleship, New Jersey has rich land and a powerful army of justice

The Eagle Union has great industrial and technological power, and New Jersey uses these powers against the unrighteous: the Eagle Union can easily build a strong and leading army, and the [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength and [ICON_Movement] Movement bonus that New Jersey declares to liberate, reconquest, and protectorate is even more unstoppable. Using trade routes with the city-states to unite the city-states, combined with the power of the Eagle Union, New Jersey can crush all evil forces. New Jersey will effectively protect the Eagle Union from infringement, thereby maximizing the advantages of the Eagle Union civilization in the Science Victory. Of course, with the support of so many city-states, New Jersey did equally well in its diplomatic victories.

USS New Jersey is the Iowa-class battleship No. 2 built by the United States Navy in the early years of World War II and the second ship of the United States Navy to be named after New Jersey. New Jersey has a well-known nickname, the "Garden State" – New Jersey does not have many gardens, but once prides itself on large farms. This did not praise New Jersey's rich agricultural output, but the ultimate purpose was proposed in 1876 to protest the New Yorkers in the north and the Pennsylvans in the west seizing the resources of the state's farms and asking the citizens to stand up and "defend their garden state", Abraham Browning, who was the state attorney general, called New Jersey the Garden State in his speech, saying that New Jersey was like a vat full of food, with open mouths at both ends, Pennsylvanians scooping up good food from one end and leaving the other to New Yorkers. Now this nickname has no political connotations, and as a state that straddles the two large urban agglomerations of New York and Philadelphia, New Jersey is indeed advantageous.

For the Iowa class battleships, everyone may be more familiar with the lead Iowa and the No. 3 ship Missouri, but the No. 2 ship New Jersey, also known as "Big J" and "Black Dragon", also has a very special place in the history of the US Navy:

Here we need to explain the composition of the US Pacific Fleet during World War II: when it comes to the US Pacific Fleet, everyone's first impression may be "powerful" and "meritorious". During World War II, the U.S. Navy's Pacific Fleet, under the command of Commander-in-Chief Admiral Nimitz, fought against the naval forces of an entire country in the old Japanese Empire from the western coastline of the United States, to Pearl Harbor in Hawaii, to the Central Pacific Islands, the South Pacific and Australia, and finally to Southeast Asia and the Japanese mainland. The core sequence of this fleet, which confronted the Combined Fleet head-on in World War II, was the Third Fleet/Fifth Fleet, the 38/58th Task Force, dubbed the "Annihilation Fleet", which was officially the most elite main force of the fleet.

- Yes, since New Jersey appeared on the front line of the Pacific theater in early 1944, she has been favored by William Halsey Jr. and Spruance, the two leaders of the Pacific Fleet, and has almost always served as the flagship of the Third Fleet/Fifth Fleet, as the seat of two legendary fleet commanders. Although the most difficult moment of the US Navy in the Pacific had passed by then, the victory of the war still required the final blow of the righteous division, and New Jersey witnessed all this as the flagship of the fleet, all the way to the Gulf of Tonkin, until the American troops sent home ...

New Jersey's flagship career during World War II was generally characterized by one thing - although it was the flagship of the fleet, New Jersey never avoided war. If battleships were needed to provide support, New Jersey would certainly not take care of the fleet commander on board the ships, accurately appearing in battle positions, or even at the forefront of the battlefield.

During World War II, New Jersey participated in successive battles in the Marshall Islands and Kwajalein, serving as the flagship of the Fifth Fleet before attacking Truk Mooring, Palau and Wallay Atoll, briefly stepping down as the flagship of the fleet to support the landing in New Guinea, and finally participating in the Battle of the Philippine Sea. Fleet commanders rotated to serve as flagship of the Third Fleet, participated in the Battle of Leyte Gulf, and supported the U.S. forces in retaking the Philippines. After stepping down as the flagship of the Third Fleet, he supported the attack on Iwo Jima, advanced to Okinawa, and eventually re-entered Tokyo Bay as the flagship of the Fifth Fleet. After World War II, the main force of the Pacific Fleet was replaced by the Seventh Fleet, and New Jersey unsurprisingly became the flagship of the Seventh Fleet, participating in the Korean War, the Vietnam War, and the Lebanese Civil War, but it was Missouri and Wisconsin who did not participate in the Gulf War, and finally retired before the Gulf War. Now, New Jersey is moored as a museum ship in the Camden Harbor area of New Jersey, where the former New York shipyard is located - returning to the former shipbuilding industry town with such a naval tradition in New Jersey.

During World War II, New Jersey received a total of 9 Battle Stars. But if she includes years of post-war campaigning, New Jersey has earned 16 Battle Stars throughout her service career. During the Vietnam War, New Jersey was collectively commended by the Navy; It also received collective commendations from the Presidents of the Philippines and South Korea.
Therefore, American war history researchers have a position on her historical status, she is "the most honorable battleship in the history of the United States Navy".
Black Dragon
Willing to wage wars of liberation, reconquest and protectorate, admire the leaders of the liberated city. Disgusted the leaders that launch surprise wars or attacking the city-states.
(You declared a surprise war)
New Jersey hated people who declared surprise wars
(You liberated a city)
New Jersey is glad to see you liberate cities to fight for justice
(You fight for the city-state)
New Jersey is glad to see you protect the city-state
New Jersey hated those who threatened the city-state
(You attack the city-state)
New Jersey hated those who attacked the city-state
Firepower for Freedom

Can declare a War of Liberation after gaining the Defensive Tactics Civic. +5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength, +2 [ICON_Movement] Movement, +100% [icon_PRODUCTION] Production within 10 turns after the War of Liberation, Reconquest and Defense of the City-State. +5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength for all units when at war. Each [ICON_TradeRoute] Trade Route sent to a City-State awards 2 [ICON_ENVOY] Envoy there. +1 [ICON_Food] Food, +1 [ICON_Culture] Culture, +3 [ICON_Gold] Gold for all Farms, Pastures, Camps and Plantation improvements. Gain the Iowa-class battleship unique unit when the Advanced Ballistics technology is researched.
+5, In a state of war
+5 [ICON_Strength] Combat Strength when in a state of war
Iowa-class battleships
New Jersey's unique Atomic era naval unit that replaces the Missile Cruiser, unlock earlier. Stronger than Missile Cruiser.

The Iowa-class battleships were a class of fast battleships that the United States Navy began designing in 1938 and began construction in 1940, making them the last battleships and largest battleships of the United States Navy. They were the most well-known battleships of the Second World War, combining firepower and protection with high speed performance - of all the battleships built and commissioned, the Iowa class was the longest, the most powerful, and naturally the fastest. They were also the last battleships in the world to be decommissioned, and it was not until the 1990s that four Iowa class ships were decommissioned.

During the "Naval Holiday" period, under the constraints of naval treaties, the United States successively built six cutting-edge treaty-type battleships, namely two North Carolina-class and four South Dakota-class. Their speed is around 27-28 knots. Based on the "Orange Plan" conceived by the U.S. military, in order to counter the heavy cruisers, battle cruisers and all potential high-speed combat ships of the Japanese Navy on the other side of the Pacific, and to provide escort and support for the fast aircraft carrier task force, the U.S. Navy needed to deploy a higher speed battleship. With Japan's withdrawal from the treaty in 1936 and the signing of the "upgrade clause" of the treaty in 1938, the standard displacement limit for new battleships was relaxed to 45,000 tons, and the design and construction of the new high-speed battleship envisaged by the US Navy gradually got on track.

The Iowa class was built very quickly, and the first 2 ships entered service in 43. The lead ship Iowa was designed as a flagship, with a larger conning tower, and did not have a Bofors cannon on turret 2 for better views, which is one of the important symbols that distinguishes it from its other 3 sister ships. In addition, during the construction process, the bridge structure of each ship was different. The original design was an open-air bridge similar to the South Dakota-class one, which was changed to a curved enclosed bridge shortly after New Jersey was completed, and a more space-spaced square-headed bridge in Missouri and Wisconsin, and revised to this style in 1945 by Iowa and New Jersey.

After the end of World War II, the Iowa class was re-commissioned several times as an effective and relatively inexpensive ground fire support platform. In the 1980s, a large-scale modernization was also carried out, with the ability to launch missiles. It was retired from service in the 1990s and played a role as a museum.
Floutish Garden

Unlocks the Builder ability to construct a Floutish Garden, unique to New Jersey.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]+2 [icon_PRODUCTION] Production, +2 [ICON_Culture] Culture, +1 [ICON_Housing] Housing. +1 [ICON_Food] Food and [ICON_Culture] Culture for each adjacent Farms, Pastures, Camps or Plantations. +3 [ICON_Gold] Gold for each adjacent to Floutish Gardens. +1 [icon_PRODUCTION] Production and [ICON_Gold] Gold for each adjacent Districts after studying Industrialization. It can only be built on Grassland, Grassland Hills, Plains and Plains Hills.

Row.Text: Your thoughts have been conveyed to me – and I gladly accept your friendship.
It's not that easy to be my friend.
I think you can be my friend, are you willing to accept my friendship?
Then we're friends.
Ah, so, then I'd better wait.
Oh? It's an unexpected opponent. Interesting ~ all staff, first-level combat readiness! The battle begins! Your troops will be crushed.
Standing in the way of the Eagle Union is a mistake at all times. No one can stop our will, go to war!
Your delegation has arrived in the rich Garden State, and the abundance of resources is sure to blow their minds.
We weren't ready for reception.
Please accept my delegation! With the riches of the Garden State, they will show you the courage of our people.
Hahaha! To be honest, I've faced greater difficulties than you, and I'm not that easy to back down.
I have fought across the Pacific for justice. But you are far more evil than the enemies I have ever seen. (Condemn you)

I am the Eagle Union battleship, the largest and strongest Black Dragon - the USS New Jersey. This is not a boast, or rather, "the strongest in the world" is not exaggerated~ As long as you fully understand me, you will soon dispel your doubts about this topic~
Would you like to visit a city near us to admire the riches of the "Garden State"?
Thank you.
Exchanging our information about the capital, I think, will facilitate our relationship.
I have traveled the Pacific to fight for justice, and I am glad that you can defend justice as much as I do.
Even if you don't want to fight for justice, at least don't stand against it.
I think the time is ripe for me to recognize you as our ally. Let's form an alliance.
Huge army? I think I've seen a lot.
"Maybe battleships will become obsolete, but the Iowa class won't." ...... The era of battleships ended after all.
Good, it's a deal that satisfies both parties.
No, this deal is not fair.
